Introduction

Botulism is a rare but serious paralytic illness caused by neurotoxins produced by the bacterium Clostridium botulinum.

Pathophysiology



C botulinum is a gram-positive, anaerobic bacillus that synthesizes botulinum toxin, a highly potent toxin that can be lethal in small quantities.  The toxin enters the nerve terminals through endocytosis, where it prevents binding and fusion of acetylcholine-containing synaptic vesicles with the plasma membrane through the destruction of SNARE proteins (

figure 1
).  This inhibits the presynaptic release of acetylcholine from the nerve terminal at the neuromuscular junction, which prevents both nicotinic and muscarinic receptor activation, leading to skeletal muscle weakness and reduced glandular secretions, respectively.



C botulinum forms spores, which allow the bacteria to survive adverse conditions (eg, heat).  Spores are typically isolated from environmental dust/soil (particularly where soil is disturbed such as agricultural areas) and various foods, including raw honey, seafood, fruits, and vegetables.  The anaerobic environment within certain foods that are fermented, preserved, or canned at home (where improper processing can lead to contamination by viable C botulinum spores) allows for germination and growth of the organism.

Epidemiology and risk factors



There are 3 common types of botulism, categorized by how they occur:



  • Infant botulism (

    ):  This is the most common type, accounting for approximately 75% of cases.  Although it has classically been associated with the ingestion of raw honey, most cases occur from the ingestion of dust/soil.  Infants have an immature digestive system that allows for spore germination, which causes C botulinum to colonize the gastrointestinal tract and produce botulinum toxin in situ.
  • Foodborne botulism (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ):  This type occurs due to ingestion of contaminated food that has preformed botulinum toxin in it.  It usually occurs through the consumption of fermented/aged foods (particularly seafood) or foods canned at home.
  • Wound botulism:  C botulinum can infect wounds (typically deep puncture wounds), including those caused by injection drug use.  The bacteria can replicate within the wound, which may provide an ideal anaerobic environment, and subsequently release the toxin in vivo.

Clinical presentation

General presentation



Patients with botulism typically have:



  • Bilateral cranial nerve deficits leading to oculobulbar weakness, including oculomotor (CN III), trochlear (CN IV), and abducens (CN VI) nerves, causing ophthalmoplegia, ptosis, or mydriasis; facial nerve (CN VII), causing facial weakness; and/or glossopharyngeal (CN IX) and vagus (CN X), causing dysphagia or suppressed gag
  • Symmetric descending weakness with progression from the upper extremities to the lower extremities
  • Autonomic dysfunction (eg, constipation, urinary retention, and/or dry mouth)
  • Respiratory compromise from involvement of the diaphragm, sometimes requiring mechanical ventilation


Because they are caused by the release of a preformed toxin, systemic inflammatory symptoms are usually absent, and most patients are afebrile and alert with normal heart rate and blood pressure.  Deep tendon reflexes are preserved (unless complete muscle paralysis occurs) and sensation is usually intact.

Infant botulism



Infants with botulism may present subtly.  They often initially have constipation followed days to weeks later by nonspecific symptoms of weakness, lethargy, and reduced feeding.  They can subsequently develop oculobulbar symptoms, which can manifest as ptosis, impaired pupillary constriction, weak suck and cry, and/or diminished gag reflex.  Symmetric, descending flaccid paralysis including the extremities follows, with loss of head control and hypotonia that can cause the infant to have a floppy appearance.

Foodborne botulism



Patients with foodborne botulism develop symptoms acutely within 36 hours of toxin ingestion.  They often present with gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain, followed by more classic signs.

Wound botulism



Those who develop wound botulism may have associated fever and leukocytosis, usually due to concomitant bacterial infection of the wound.  Wound botulism generally presents ~10 days after transmission.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of botulism can be difficult due to the rarity of the disease and its similarities to other neurologic conditions such as myasthenia gravis or Guillain-BarrÃ© syndrome.  Botulism should be suspected in any patient with signs and symptoms of cranial nerve deficits without a fever.  Diagnosis is primarily clinical, based on history and physical examination findings (eg, cranial nerve deficits with symmetric descending paralysis without other systemic symptoms).



Although not necessary for the diagnosis, cerebrospinal fluid analysis and neuroimaging are obtained in many patients to rule out other disorders.  In botulism, these tests are usually normal.  Electrodiagnostic evaluation (eg, electromyography with repetitive nerve stimulation) can be used to support the diagnosis.  Electromyography may show a decrease in the compound muscle action potential (or electrical response of the muscle) following stimulation of a motor nerve.  High-rate, repetitive nerve stimulation improves the deficit because a rapid depolarization rate increases calcium concentration in the presynaptic nerve terminal, helping mobilize additional acetylcholine vesicles.



Identification of C botulinum spores or toxins from serum, stool, gastric aspirate, a suspected food source, or a wound is confirmatory.  Serum samples are frequently negative in cases of infant botulism, so stool samples are preferred.

Differential diagnosis



  • Guillain-BarrÃ© syndrome:  an autoimmune demyelinating disorder classically triggered after Campylobacter jejuni infection.  Patients can have a progressive, symmetric weakness that may involve cranial nerves.  However, the paralysis is typically ascending (eg, starting in the legs), and patients usually also have paresthesias and areflexia, which are not characteristic of botulism.
  • Myasthenia gravis:  an autoimmune disorder characterized by circulating antibodies against acetylcholine receptors.  Although patients often have ptosis and diplopia, pupillary abnormalities (eg, mydriasis) are uncommon, and weakness is fatigable and fluctuating rather than progressive in a descending fashion like in botulism.
  • Multiple sclerosis:  can present with diplopia due to cranial nerve deficits (eg, abducens nerve [CN VI]) or lesions involving the medial longitudinal fasciculus (coordinates gaze).  However, patients experience neurologic deficits disseminated in time and space.  Pupillary constriction and ptosis are not typical for multiple sclerosis.
  • Tetanus:  a neuromuscular disease caused by the toxin-producing Clostridium tetani.  However, tetanus usually causes tonic contraction of skeletal muscles (eg, trismus, rigid abdomen) and severe muscle spasms.
  • Stroke:  can present with focal neurologic deficits, including weakness and cranial nerve abnormalities, but symptoms are usually sudden onset, whereas botulism may have a more gradual onset over hours to days.
  • Bacterial meningitis:  can present in infants as poor feeding, weakness, and hypotonia.  However, fever and a bulging fontanelle are common concomitant symptoms.

Management



Management of suspected botulism includes hospital admission in an intensive care setting with cardiopulmonary monitoring for respiratory failure.  Immediate intubation is required in patients with clinical or laboratory signs of impending respiratory failure, including poor respiratory effort, inability to clear secretions, absent gag reflex, hypoxia, and hypercarbia.



The primary treatment for botulism is antitoxin therapy, with either botulism immunoglobulin for infant botulism or equine serum botulinum antitoxin for all other cases.  It should be administered as soon as the diagnosis is suspected and should not be delayed while awaiting confirmatory studies.

Prognosis



The prognosis for botulism varies depending on the severity of the disease.  A full recovery is typical with early administration of botulism antitoxin.  The antitoxin binds circulating neurotoxin and limits the progression of neurologic symptoms but cannot reverse paralysis.  Because of the prolonged duration of action of botulinum toxin, hospitalization is often required for weeks to months as the initial weakness and paralysis slowly improve.  Severe cases may be associated with significant morbidity and mortality, particularly in the absence of timely supportive care.

Prevention



Botulism that occurs from contaminated food can be prevented by proper food handling and avoiding canned foods that show signs of damage.  The spores can be destroyed at very high temperatures (120 C [248 F] for 5 minutes), so disease can be prevented by thoroughly heating home canned food prior to consumption.  Honey should also be avoided in children age <12 months to help prevent the occurrence of infant botulism.

Summary



Botulism is a rare but potentially life-threatening illness caused by neurotoxins produced by Clostridium botulinum.  The pathogenesis involves toxin destruction of SNARE proteins, which inhibits the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.  Botulism is divided into 3 typical categories: infant botulism, foodborne botulism, and wound botulism.  Patients typically present with cranial nerve dysfunction, descending flaccid paralysis, autonomic dysfunction, and lack of fever.  Diagnosis is based on clinical evaluation and confirmation of the presence of botulinum toxin.  Management involves supportive care and the administration of botulinum antitoxin.  Recovery can take weeks to months.
